title: Data Stewardship for ocean data
text:
This site contains information and resources about the principles and practices of stewarding ocean data. The content was delivered as three sessions for the Operational Oceanography students at Rutgers University in fall 2025/winter 2026.

What is data stewardship?
It is the actions involved in supporting, promoting, and guiding the use and reuse of data throughout the data lifecycle.


Why does it matter?

enables faster, better science
connects your data to new insights
gets you credit for your data work
preserves knowledge for the future

title: Key terms and principles
text:
A more expansive list of terms can be found in our glossary. If you would like to suggest a term to be added to the glossary, please make an issue in the GitHub repository.

Metadata
Information that describes the data
This is the information someone else needs to understand and reuse your data. It might describe a sensor deployment, a tag deployment, definitions of column names, units in which variables were measured, or project information.
Some types of metadata used in ocean science include EML, ISO19115, and Darwin Core.


FAIR principles
Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable
These principles were first published in Scientific Data in 2016, and have been widely adopted by many organizations and people who work with data. How the principles are put into action and measured are topics of active research and development.
A good place to learn more is the GO FAIR Foundation.


Licensing
Defines what a user is allowed to do with a dataset
Licensing makes the terms of reuse explicit to the user. Check with your organization or institution and any other data owners to assist in choosing a license. Choose the least restrictive license to ensure the widest possible reuse of the data.
Information about Creative Commons licences and their license chooser tool. Information about licenses for code and software at the Open Source Initiative.


PID
Persistent identifier, e.g. ORCiD, DOI, ROR
These identifiers help disambiguate people, research products, and organizations. They support getting credit for your work or funding, and finding digital objects.
An overview of types of PIDs can be found here.


DMSP (aka DMP and other related terms)
Data Management & Sharing Plan
This document describes a project’s outputs; how they will be managed and shared.
One tool for creating these plans is DMPTool.

title: Data Lifecycle
text:
These are the stages data often goes through during a research project, but they are also how we think about data going from idea to impactful information.



Data lifecycle (Click to enlarge)


At each stage of the data lifecycle, we’ve highlighted some data stewardship actions that can be taken. These are not comprehensive though.

title: Data Literacy
text:
Knowledge that enables understanding and communicating about data in appropriate and meaningful ways throughout the data lifecycle.
Data stewardship requires practitioners to be data literate, and includes three key components:

finding data
evaluating data and metadata
understanding licenses and reuse terms 


Finding data
The first step to finding data is knowing what you’re searching for. It can be helpful to list the characteristics the data must fulfill in order to be useful in your project or for your research question.
This article includes eleven tips for finding data.
Gregory K, Khalsa SJ, Michener WK, Psomopoulos FE, de Waard A, Wu M (2018) Eleven quick tips for finding research data. PLoS Comput Biol 14(4): e1006038. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006038 


Evaluating data

Check under which terms and conditions the data is shared
Check whether there is sufficient metadata to enable data reuse
Assess the quality of the data - Does it come from a trusted source, and does it adhere to a standard?
Has the data been ethically collected and shared?
Does the data include a persistent identifier (e.g. DOI) so you can properly give credit to the data creators? 



Understanding licenses
Frequently used licenses for data, figures, maps, articles, and other digital outputs include:

CC0

CC-BY

Also see the Creative Commons license chooser tool.
Common licenses for code and software include:

MIT

Apache

CDDL

GPL

More information about licenses for code and software can be found at the Open Source Initiative.

title: Data Stewardship Glossary
text:
Calibrated Data
This glossary is meant to serve as a useful reference. It is an evergreen document and will be updated and added to as often as necessary.
Time series data that has been processed using software to apply instrument calibration (to compare acoustic measurements to a known standard). From PAM Data Mgmt Best Practices.
